author: inan0812
content:
So, did I hear correctly today in the EIP-1559 call that the Devs are cool with miners manipulating the blocks to snipe arbitrage plays from other entities?

Today we have high fees because they are outbidding eachother. Whereas miners can just submit the same transaction at 1 Wei and guarantee it executes as long as we mine the block.

Sounded like they were cool with that. Might drive a lot of capital out of ETH from entities strictly performing arbitrage plays, but we're cool?

author: sky.cactus
content: I actively encourage it.  ðŸ™‚

author: sky.cactus
content:
My design philosophy is that a system like this cannot/should not be secure merely because:
A. One group of participants do not know how to leverage their position selfishly.
B. One group participants choose not to leverage their position selfishly.

author: sky.cactus
content: MEV is a thing, and if Ethereum isn't secure when miners actively extract that value, then Ethereum isn't secure and that **should** be addressed.

author: donschoe
content: How does the inclusion gas fee differ from current gas fee market assumptions from a user perspective ? The base gas fee is burned but miners can still rank transactions by inclusion fee, couldn't they? So the gas market competition is still on and is solely relaxed by the fact that block size is much more dynamic (elasticity), isn't it?

content:
Oh damn, this prevents miners from colluding to jack up fees?

Why are we not currently colluding to prevent transactions below 300 gwei?

Seems logical right? Oh wait, because it would potentially destabilize the platform and make users, investors and developers avoid ETH, reducing our ROI in the mid-long term.

author: inan0812
content: But yes, fee burn is necessary because there are proofs that focus on certain variables and assume no others are relevant.

author: sky.cactus
content: Miners still will sort by fee most likely (though that is non-consensus so they don't have to).

author: sky.cactus
content: Yes, the elasticity of the block size and the automated adjustment of the base fee to *target* a 50% full block is what creates the UX improvement.

author: sky.cactus
content: If base_fee is 100, you know that if you set max_fee to 200 you will get in as long as there isn't 6 blocks in a row of sudden 2x congestion, and you'll also never pay more than the minimum required for inclusion.

author: sky.cactus
content: It makes gas pricing turn into "assert how much you are willing to pay" instead of "guess how much other people are willing to pay in the near future".

author: justinjja
content:
Without burning it becomes a lot easier, 
a single pool can make a bunch of fake transactions and NOT broadcast them.
And only mine them when they mine their own block.
So they artificially fill the blocks and it costs them nothing.

And if you wonder about ways to solve this without burning see <#798586271445680129>

author: inan0812
content:
That's not accurate. 

If there is a mandatory base fee that is high, it will cost them more to fill the block will null transactions, right?

But the actual block they mine with these higher fees will only reward the pool by a  set percent, usually 1%.

So it will cost them to fill the block, and if the base fee doesn't scale quickly, since only 2 pools mine >=25% of blocks, they will just be eating fees.

author: justinjja
content:
Right now fees go to the miner that mines the block.

So lets say I have room for 1000 transactions and there are only 500 pending transactions.
I can spend $5000 making 500 fake transactions,
But if I mine the block, that $5000 comes back to me.

With 1559 that $5000 is burned so I can no longer artificially fill blocks.

author: inan0812
content:
As a solo miner, yes. You forgo getting actual revenue, get your money back, and increase the next base fee.


As a pool, you lose money, or defraud your miners and risk losing them.

author: justinjja
content:
"forgo getting actual revenue" in my example above no revenue is missed.
You get the full block reward + all the fees from the 500 real transactions.

author: inan0812
content:
Ah, yes, my bad. As a solo miner, you don't lose anything by doing this. So, small burn disincentive this.

As a pool, you lose 99% of the fake transaction to your miners.

author: justinjja
content:
You are assuming the pool want's to do it secretly...
It's going to be pretty obvious a pool is doing this if their blocks are all full.
But with 1559 the fee is built into the protocol, so there isn't anything you can do about it (other than forking to burn fees eventually)
